author: By Madeleine Feeny
title: A French Thriller About a Kidfluencer Gone Missing
description: Delphine de Vigan’s “Kids Run the Show” skewers the phenomenon of parents exposing their children to the world for personal gain.
content: “You have to see it to believe it,” a police officer says of a mom vlogger’s YouTube channel in Delphine de Vigan’s agenda-setting literary thriller, which shines a light on the murky ethics of putting your family on social media. “Seriously, do people even know this exists?” It’s a pertinent question, because unless you have children, and carefully monitor their digital consumption, this billion-dollar industry could easily fly under your radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
title: Reports Say Pope Francis Is Evicting U.S. Cardinal From His Vatican Home
description: Word of the action against Cardinal Raymond Burke came after the prelate’s increasingly pointed critiques of the reform-minded pope.
content: Almost as soon as Pope Francis became the head of the Roman Catholic church in 2013, Raymond Burke, an American cardinal, emerged as his leading critic from within the church, becoming a de facto antipope for frustrated traditionalists who believed Francis was diluting doctrine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Popular Science Shuts Online Magazine in Another Sign of Decline
description: The decision came three years after the publication ended its storied print edition, which began in 1872. It will still publish articles and videos on its website.
content: In yet another sign of its decline, Popular Science has stopped publishing its online magazine, three years after it shut its storied print edition, which began in 1872.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: How to Kill a Palestinian State
description: A growing fraction of the progressive left is making common cause with some of the worst people on earth.
content: Do the people chanting “Free Palestine” and “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” have any idea of the irreparable harm they’re doing to any hope of Palestinian sovereignty?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: How to Watch the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree Lighting
description: The 91st annual celebration will take place on Wednesday and feature performances by Cher, Barry Manilow, Keke Palmer and others.
content: The Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center will be illuminated by more than 50,000 multicolored lights on Wednesday, kicking off a Midtown Manhattan holiday tradition that dates back to the 1930s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
title: After More Than 2 Weeks, Rescue Arrives for Workers Trapped in Indian Tunnel
description: After repeated mechanical setbacks, the operation turned to trained miners using manual tools to clear the final stretch of debris.
content: After a 17-day effort to free dozens of Indian construction workers trapped inside a Himalayan road tunnel, rescuers finally cleared a path through debris on Tuesday and pulled the men out, ending an excruciating wait for the workers and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy, Samar Abu Elouf and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Fearful, Humiliated and Desperate: Gazans Heading South Face Horrors
description: Tens of thousands of Gazans are making the most difficult of choices, leaving their homes behind to survive.
content: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Sailor Mother
description: A family struggles to pull their mom away from the call of the sea.
content: Sarah writes: My mother sails every weekend and often throughout the week. It’s not uncommon to try to plan a family event, only for her to ask that it be rescheduled to a time she wouldn’t prefer to be sailing, like nighttime or during a storm. Such events include my brother’s 40th birthday, baby showers and even my wedding. Please ask her to stop this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Will Dyeing the Connecticut River Help Keep It Alive?
description: Hydrilla, a rapidly spreading invasive plant, is choking New England’s longest river. Government scientists are fighting back.
content: The Connecticut River faces a crisis: An aggressive invasive plant that grows in thick underwater mats is spreading swiftly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: How to Watch the DeSantis-Newsom Debate
description: The unusual event, between a Republican presidential candidate and a high-profile Democratic governor who has been a surrogate for the Biden administration, will be moderated by Sean Hannity.
content: Fox News will host a 90-minute debate between Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison
title: Fed Officials Hint That Rate Increases Are Over, and Investors Celebrate
description: Stocks and bonds were buoyed after even inflation-focused Federal Reserve officials suggested that rates may stay steady.
content: Federal Reserve officials appear to be dialing back the chances of future interest rate increases, after months in which they have carefully kept the possibility of further policy changes alive for fear that inflation would prove stubborn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: New Bidder Aims to Save Bankrupt Trucking Firm, if Creditors Go Along
description: The plan would put Yellow back on the road with thousands of unionized drivers, but would force the government to wait longer for a loan repayment.
content: When Yellow abruptly shuttered its operations in the summer and filed for bankruptcy protection, few thought that a buyer would emerge and try to revive the long-troubled trucking giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The 10 Best California Books of 2023
description: These new works of fiction and nonfiction vividly render the state’s past and present.
content: Believe it or not, the end of 2023 is approaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Past Lives’ and Lily Gladstone Win Big at the Gotham Awards
description: The movie prize season kicks off with honors for the A24 drama and for the star of “The Unknown Country” (who’s better known for “Killers of the Flower Moon”).
content: “Past Lives,” the elegiac drama about a young Korean immigrant and the romantic path not taken, won best feature at the 33rd annual Gotham Awards, which were handed out Monday night at Cipriani Wall Street in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Extends Detention of American Reporter
description: The decision means that the journalist, Evan Gershkovich, who has denied the espionage charge against him, will remain in custody until Jan. 30.
content: A Moscow court on Tuesday extended the pretrial detention of Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who has been held in Russia for nearly eight months on an espionage charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government vehemently reject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and César Rodríguez
title: Americans Love Avocados. It’s Killing Mexico’s Forests.
description: Illegal deforestation for avocado crops points to a blood-soaked trade with the United States involving threats, abductions and killings.
content: First the trucks arrived, carrying armed men toward the mist-shrouded mountaintop. Then the flames appeared, sweeping across a forest of towering pines and oaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: New York City Ballet and Its Orchestra Reach Contract Deal
description: The agreement, which includes an increase in compensation of about 22 percent over three years, ends months of tense negotiations.
content: After months of wrangling, New York City Ballet and the union representing its musicians announced on Tuesday they had reached a deal for a new contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Tullis
title: How Geert Wilders Won
description: The Netherlands, where rural areas are losing physicians, bus stops and schools while urban areas thrive, is fertile ground for a demagogue.
content: A country where depopulating rural areas are losing physicians, bus stops and elementary schools while urban areas thrive is fertile ground for a demagogue — say, a politician who crusades against Islam, immigrants and the forces of globalization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Holly Maguigan, Who Fought for the Rights of Battered Women, Dies at 78
description: Through her scholarship and her teaching, she made it possible for women in abusive relationships to claim self-defense when fighting back.
content: Holly Maguigan, a law professor who drew on her years as a criminal defense lawyer to revolutionize the legal tools available to women who defend themselves against abusive partners, died on Nov. 15 in Manhattan. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Even Most Biden Voters Don’t See a Thriving Economy
description: A majority of those who backed President Biden in 2020 say today’s economy is fair or poor, ordinarily a bad omen for incumbents seeking re-election.
content: Presidents seeking a second term have often found the public’s perception of the economy a pivotal issue. It was a boon to Ronald Reagan; it helped usher Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush out of the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall D. Eliason
title: Why Judges in the Trump Jan. 6 Trial Need a Rocket Docket
description: Voters could go to the polls in 2024 without knowing whether one of the candidates is criminally responsible for trying to overturn the last one.
content: If Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for president in 2024, it’s now clear he will likely still have criminal indictments hanging over his head on Election Day. It’s possible that his criminal liability for the events leading up to the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol will remain unresolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: In New Zealand’s Crackdown on Crime, What Part Can Maori Wardens Play?
description: The strategies used by the Indigenous community policing alternative are in stark contrast to more muscular tactics pitched by the incoming government.
content: As tempers flared on a recent evening in a nightlife district in Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, Joanne Paikea sensed an altercation — or even an arrest — brewing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Hamburger America, From a Burger Documentarian, Opens in the Village
description: Partridge brings holiday cheer to the Standard, East Village, bars pop up for the holiday and more restaurant news.
content: Imagine if, after publishing her flagship tomes, Julia Child had opened a French restaurant. George Motz has done something along those lines. The genial, whiskered filmmaker, a Long Island native, has spent decades chronicling the hamburger on TV, in guidebooks and cookbooks. He can now be seen pressing and seasoning onion-thatched portions of ground beef on the griddle at his first Hamburger America, a sunny restaurant with counter seats, booths and takeout, in SoHo. The restaurant’s name is that of his 2004 documentary film, a project that took him around the country researching hamburgers, and subsequent guidebook. In partnership with the owners of the Schnipper’s casual American restaurants, he serves a flattened fried onion burger with American cheese, and a classic smashburger with optional cheese and condiments, $7.25 for a single on a toasted, buttered potato roll, or $11.50 for a double. The meat is prime chuck, 75 percent lean. As for why the smashed burgers, they go back to what he says were the original hamburgers sold in the United States for more than 100 years. “I like history,” he said. There are fries, a few sandwiches, flavored milks including a chocolate egg cream, and Miller High Life, as well. Early next year he will invite guest hamburger makers from around the country on a monthly basis to serve their specialties. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Martin
title: I Wanna Be Curated: Can You Really Put Punk in a Museum?
description: In Las Vegas, the answer is a resounding yes — and why not throw in a wedding chapel and a bar, too?
content: Fat Mike likes to be on time — to “put the punk in punctual,” as he says. So he was mildly distressed to be a few minutes late meeting me at the new Punk Rock Museum in Las Vegas, of which he is a founder and the public face. I had pleasantly cooled my heels at the museum’s bar, the Triple Down. At the Triple Down, you can order a Fletcher, a double rum and Coke served in an emptied Pringles can, named for Fletcher Dragge, guitarist for the band Pennywise and a member of the museum’s governing “Punk Collective.” (You get the chips on the side.) Or you might choose a Double Fatty, honoring Fat Mike himself: a double shot of Tito’s vodka, served with lime-flavored Liquid Death sparkling water and also a shot of Jameson. Fat Mike, as he told me within five minutes of his arrival, was a first-round investor in Liquid Death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao and Lazaro Gamio
title: Here are the statuses of the hostages taken into Gaza on Oct. 7.
description: Eighty-five of the roughly 240 people captured have now been released.
content: Hamas released 10 Israeli hostages and two Thai nationals on Tuesday as the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas continued into a fifth day, raising the total number of captives released to 85. Roughly 240 hostages were captured on Oct. 7, when Hamas led devastating raids into Israel and killed about 1,200 people, according to the Israeli authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We’d Lost the American Dream’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: When we lost our apartment, my job and your nest egg in the 2008 recession, you suggested we move into your van and drive south to stretch the paycheck you earned online. It was just you, me and our dog. Then I got pregnant in Peru, and we continued on with our baby in tow to Patagonia. We’d lost the American dream, but through life’s twists, we found a different one, on the road. After 14 years, 23 countries and four continents, we ditched the van but are still chasing new horizons, redefining what it means to be “better-off.” — Stevie Trujillo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Wife of Gilgo Beach Suspect Gets a Documentary Deal
description: Rex Heuermann is accused of killing three women. Where some saw depravity, others saw a chance to make a show.
content: After Rex Heuermann was arrested in July and accused of slaughtering women found bound in burlap and buried along a desolate stretch of Gilgo Beach, his family was left reeling and destitute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: More Hostages Were Released From Gaza
description: Also, the Koch brothers’ political group endorsed Nikki Haley. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Twelve hostages who had been held captive by Hamas since its Oct. 7 attack on Israel were released today, as the cease-fire entered a fifth day and appeared to be holding. Not long afterward, the Israeli authorities said they had released another 30 imprisoned Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: Now, What Was I Looking For?
description: Why your short-term memory falters, and how to make it better.
content: Q: Some thoughts vanish from my brain as soon as I think of them. Why can’t I remember things I just knew? And how can I improve my short-term memory?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Bidenomics and the Guys in the Bar
description: Yes, workers are better off than they were a few years ago.
content: Ten finance guys are drinking in a bar. Nine of them are Masters of the Universe — wheeler-dealers who make many millions of dollars every year. The tenth is what Gordon Gekko, in the movie “Wall Street,” called a “$400,000-a-year working Wall Street stiff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Amid Falling Walls’ Review: Songs of Resilience From the Holocaust Era
description: A new musical from National Yiddish Theater Folksbiene stitches together music written and performed in Eastern Europe in the 1930s and ’40s.
content: With the war between Israel and Hamas keeping much of the world on tenterhooks, and the tide of antisemitism evidently rising, now is either a perfect time, or far too painful a time, for “Amid Falling Walls,” a new Yiddish-language musical set during the Holocaust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Tesla Sues Swedish Transport Agency in Dispute Over License Plates
description: The electric carmaker sued the agency to deliver license plates for its cars, the latest escalation as a labor fight enters its second month.
content: Tesla sued Sweden’s Transport Agency on Monday over a strike by postal workers that has blocked delivery of license plates for Tesla cars, the latest escalation of a widening battle between Sweden’s labor unions and the U.S. manufacturer of electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand’s New Government Says It Will Scrap Smoking Ban
description: The law, celebrated as a model for other countries, would have eventually made tobacco illegal.
content: New Zealand’s new right-wing government has said it will repeal a law that would have gradually banned all cigarette sales in the country over the course of several decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Vietnam Relied on Environmentalists to Secure Billions. Then It Jailed Them.
description: The government is preparing to present its energy transition plan at the U.N. climate talks as it intensifies a crackdown on environmental advocates.
content: When Vietnam was awarded a multibillion-dollar deal by a group of nine wealthy nations last year to work on reducing its use of coal, it agreed to regularly consult with nongovernmental organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Hunter Biden Offers to Testify in House Inquiry, but Only in Public
description: The Republican chairman of the Oversight Committee quickly rejected the offer, saying the president’s son must first provide testimony behind closed doors.
content: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, who is the subject of an investigation by House Republicans into his family, told Congress on Tuesday that he was willing to testify — but only publicly so that Republicans cannot twist or selectively leak what he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Robert Battle Had a Wide Vision of What Alvin Ailey Could Be
description: Battle, the artistic director who brought Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater into a new century, resigned just before the company’s new City Center season.
content: When Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opens its annual season at New York City Center on Wednesday, it will be missing an important person: Robert Battle, the company’s jovial artistic director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Rob Reiner Teases Details of ‘Spinal Tap’ Sequel
description: Speaking on a podcast this week, the director said Paul McCartney and Elton John will appear in the film, among other real musical stars.
content: The director Rob Reiner has said that an upcoming sequel to his 1984 documentary parody “This Is Spinal Tap” is scheduled to begin shooting in late February and will feature Paul McCartney, Elton John and Garth Brooks, among other stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Piano With a Curved Keyboard Will Star at Carnegie Hall
description: The unusual piano, made in Belgium, will make its debut in Manhattan tonight. It’s more than a foot longer than a Steinway grand.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about the unusual-looking piano that will make its Carnegie Hall debut tonight. We’ll also find out about a poll that went to big spenders, as the United States Tennis Association considers whether to build suites costing $175,000 per person at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Jordyn Holman
title: Shein, the Fast-Fashion Giant, Is Said to Have Filed for an I.P.O.
description: The retailer, founded in China, filed confidentially to take the company public in the U.S., a person familiar with the plans said.
content: Shein, the ultrafast-fashion retailer founded in China more than a decade ago, has filed confidentially for an initial public offering in the United States, according to a person familiar with the plans for the deal, who was not authorized to speak publicly about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: NATO Leaders Try to Pin Down U.S. on Ukraine Aid as Republicans Waver
description: Continued American funding for Ukraine was a key concern for leaders in the military alliance, who met as the current allocation was running down and a Ukrainian counteroffensive appeared stalled.
content: With Republicans in Congress stalling on granting Ukraine more military aid, NATO’s top diplomat warned on Tuesday that it would be “dangerous” to curtail support to the war, as member countries tried to pin down the United States on its commitments to Kyiv and as the conflict in Gaza sapped Washington’s attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Searches for Museum Leaders, With Nationalism in the Air
description: Last time the top jobs at some of the country’s most prestigious art institutions came up, many went to foreign candidates. This time, that’s unlikely.
content: For the past several weeks, dozens of candidates have been facing a five-person committee in a dark, book-lined room at Italy’s Culture Ministry, hoping to convince the panel that they should be selected to direct some of Italy’s top museums, including the Uffizi in Florence, the Capodimonte in Naples, the Brera in Milan and seven others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Can U.S.-China Student Exchanges Survive Geopolitics?
description: The flow of students between the countries has been a mainstay of their relationship, even when ties have soured. Now these exchanges, too, are under threat.
content: On a cool Saturday morning, in a hotel basement in Beijing, throngs of young Chinese gathered to do what millions had done before them: dream of an American education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Guadagnino, Jameson Montgomery, Juan A. Ramírez, John Wogan and Carmen Winant
title: The T Predictor: What We’ll Be Obsessing Over in 2024
description: We asked 46 artists, filmmakers, chefs and other creative people to forecast next year’s cultural trends. (Spoiler: We’re all going to be wearing a lot of brown.)
content: “Brown — the more ‘off,’ the better. It’s subtle and confrontational: Not a lot of colors have that versatility.” — Thebe Magugu, 30, fashion designer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Bringing Wine to a Party
description: Some hosts do not appreciate the gesture.
content: Adam writes: When we entertain, I tell people to bring nothing. What are we going to do with a bottle of wine? I don’t drink, and my husband prefers cocktails. When guests come proudly clutching some stupid gift, I berate them and force them to leave it in the car. My husband thinks this is severe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola
title: Finland to Close the Last Border Crossing With Russia for Two Weeks
description: Relations have deteriorated markedly since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the Finns accuse Moscow of orchestrating a flow of migrants in retaliation for Finland joining NATO.
content: Finland said Tuesday it was temporarily closing its only remaining open border crossing with Russia to stem an influx of asylum seekers that it accuses Moscow of orchestrating in retaliation for Finland’s decision to join NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: overture
description: This word has appeared in 77 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word overture has appeared in 77 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 2 in “Hollywood Studios Signal New Strategy by Talking With Writers” by Brooks Barnes and John Koblin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Files Suggest Climate Summit’s Leader Is Using Event to Promote Fossil Fuels
description: A leaked document has talking points for the president of the United Nations climate conference, who is an oil executive in the United Arab Emirates, to advance oil and gas deals.
content: As the host of global climate talks that begin this week, the United Arab Emirates is expected to play a central role in forging an agreement to move the world more rapidly away from coal, oil and gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Seeks to Use Trial to Challenge Findings That 2020 Election Was Fair
description: The former president’s lawyers in his federal trial on charges of trying to overturn the election are asking to collect a wide range of evidence — including on unrelated issues like Hunter Biden.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said in court papers that they planned to question the findings of several government agencies that the 2020 election was conducted fairly as part of their efforts to defend Mr. Trump against federal charges that he sought to overturn the results of the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthias Joulaud and Lucien Roux
title: ‘We Don’t Want to Let It Go’: A Family Farm in Ireland Prevails
description: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.
content: Ever since we were children, we’ve been fascinated by pastoralism. We both come from families with farming roots but grew up in the city. This enthusiasm brought us to Achill Island, off the west coast of Ireland, where sheep graze over the grassland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Israel-Hamas Truce Appears to Enter Another Day, and More
description: Plus, how money is flowing out of China and scientists are one step closer to a drug extending the lives of dogs.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: What to Watch at the U.N. Climate Talks
description: Plus how New Zealand’s Maori Wardens keep the peace.
content: Two facts loom over the COP28 U.N. climate talks, which begin tomorrow in Dubai: Earth is careening toward climate disaster, and governments are acting too slowly to avert it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Wisconsin Judge Dismisses Felony Charge in ‘Ballot Selfie’ Case
description: The debate over a candidate’s photo reflects concerns among states over selfies of ballots and of people showing how they vote.
content: A Wisconsin judge on Monday dismissed a felony charge against a  school board candidate who had posted a photograph on Facebook of a ballot with his name filled in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: U.S. Has Warned Israel to Fight More Surgically in Gaza, Officials Say
description: American officials have told the Israelis that a major bombardment risks sparking a humanitarian crisis that overwhelms the world’s capacity to respond.
content: The United States has warned Israel that it must fight more surgically and avoid further mass displacement of Palestinians in its war against Hamas to avoid a humanitarian crisis that overwhelms the world’s ability to respond, according to senior Biden administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Rare Gathering of Former First Ladies Shows Style, and Subtle Differences
description: United (mostly) in black, their differences were in the details.
content: In any other circumstance it would have been a shocking sight. But it was only fitting that in her death Rosalynn Carter, the pioneering woman who turned the role of first lady into a job, did one final thing no one else has been able to do this year: lure Melania Trump out of Mar-a-Lago and back into the public eye. Not only that, but she created a situation in which Mrs. Trump was seated right next to Michelle Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
title: Egypt Wiped Out Hepatitis C. Now It Is Trying to Help the Rest of Africa.
description: Effective drugs that have made the disease curable have yet to reach most  of the region.
content: For seven years, Sulemana Musah put almost every bit of money that came his way into his war with hepatitis C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford, Michael Gold and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats Pressure Republicans to Vote This Week to Expel Santos
description: A Democratic resolution to expel Representative George Santos aims to prevent Republican leadership from delaying action on the embattled congressman.
content: House Democrats on Tuesday moved to force a vote this week on whether to expel Representative George Santos of New York from office, a strategic effort to prevent Republican leadership from slow-rolling any bid to push one of their own out of office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Giving Tuesday
description: How can you give back this year?
content: Nov. 28 this year is known as Giving Tuesday, a day when you are invited to take a break from buying things, and, instead, show generosity to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Make Sure Your Google Accounts Are Active, or They Might Be Deleted
description: The company says it will start purging accounts, including services like Gmail and YouTube, that have been idle for two years or more.
content: If you have not used one of your Google accounts for a long time, you might want to this week. Inactive accounts will start vanishing on Dec. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Everybody’s Ejected After an N.H.L. Fight
description: All 10 skaters on the ice got a game misconduct in the Senators-Panthers game on Monday night in Ottawa.
content: Hockey is one of the most physical sports, and referees try to keep it in line by assessing penalties when a push or a trip goes too far. But on Monday night in Ottawa, the officials had enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Kevin Draper
title: For Sports Illustrated, Report About Fake Authors Is Latest Stumble
description: The venerable magazine has experienced management upheaval and staff complaints in recent years. Now there’s a question over who wrote product reviews on its site.
content: Three years ago, journalists at Sports Illustrated were worried that the venerable magazine’s new owners and operators were drastically lowering its standards. They noted reports of plagiarism, and worried about substandard writing and the use of freelance reporters with little due diligence. The journalists also wanted better pay, greater transparency during the hiring process and a guarantee that all work published on the Sports Illustrated website would be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattie Kahn
title: A Tragedy, a Symphony, a Love Story
description: This month, writer Suleika Jaouad revisits her second bone marrow transplant in the documentary “American Symphony.”
content: In the months following her second bone marrow transplant, Suleika Jaouad’s TikTok algorithm started serving her videos of bearded dragons shedding their skin. For a writer whose work deals in ambiguities, that metaphor was tidier than she’d have preferred.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Rangers, Indonesian Women Guard the Forest They Live In
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 28, 2023.
content: “When we meet them, we start with small chitchat while offering some snacks and coffee. We don’t go all alpha like the men, thus the situation never heightens.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Nikki Haley Is Coming for Your Retirement
description: Wall Street’s new favorite is far from a populist.
content: It feels like years ago, but actually only a few months have passed since many big Republican donors seemed to believe that Ron DeSantis could effectively challenge Donald Trump for the Republican nomination. It has been an edifying spectacle — an object lesson in the reality that great wealth need not be associated with good judgment, about politics or anything else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: For Her Next Round, Toni Tipton-Martin Orders Up a Book of Cocktails
description: The author of “The Jemima Code” has distilled 200 years of African American drinking know-how into her new “Juke Joints, Jazz Clubs and Juice.”
content: While many in the world of cocktails are familiar with Tom Bullock, renowned for his juleps and long considered the first African American bartender to publish a cocktail manual, fewer know the work of Atholene Peyton, a home economics teacher whose 1906 “Peytonia Cook Book” predated Bullock’s by a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: In Canada, a Judge Sentences an Incel Killer as a Terrorist
description: A Toronto teenager who killed a woman in a massage business was sentenced on Tuesday to life in prison. The case was the first time gender-based violence in the country was labeled terrorism.
content: The teenager was lying next to his bloodied sword when the police captured him outside a Toronto massage business where one woman had been stabbed to death and another seriously injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: How Mortadella Went From Cold Cut to Hot Item
description: Helped by its millennial-pink hue and the rise of the charcuterie board, the Italian specialty is winning a new fan base of American chefs and consumers.
content: By the standards of Bologna, Simona Scapin is a mortadella upstart. That’s not only because she’s young and the sole local producer of certified organic mortadella. Nor is it just because her family has been making mortadella for a mere four decades in the city where the recipe was ordained by papal authority in 1661.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Swan
title: Koch Network Endorses Nikki Haley in Bid to Push G.O.P. Past Trump
description: The support will give Ms. Haley more organizational strength in the field as she battles Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for the No. 2 spot in the Republican presidential race.
content: The political network founded by the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch has endorsed Nikki Haley in the Republican presidential nominating contest, giving her organizational muscle and financial heft as she battles Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to be the top rival to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Robert D. Hershey Jr
title: Charles T. Munger, Much More Than Warren Buffett’s No. 2, Dies at 99
description: A billionaire himself, he was the witty vice chairman of Mr. Buffett’s powerhouse investment firm Berkshire Hathaway. But he had far more influence than his title suggested.
content: Charles T. Munger, who quit a well-established law career to be Warren E. Buffett’s partner and maxim-spouting alter-ego as they transformed a foundering New England textile company into the spectacularly successful investment firm Berkshire Hathaway, died on Tuesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Cancels Trip to U.N. Climate Summit on Doctor’s Orders
description: Days after the pontiff was forced to slow down because of a flu, his doctors advised him to not travel to Dubai for COP28. Francis has made climate activism a hallmark of his papacy.
content: Pope Francis, following his doctor’s orders, will not attend the United Nations climate summit in Dubai later this week, the Vatican said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Joy Dong
title: Gold Bars and Tokyo Apartments: How Money Is Flowing Out of China.
description: Chinese families are sending money overseas, a sign of worry about the country’s economic and political future. But a cheaper currency is also helping exports.
content: Affluent Chinese have moved hundreds of billions of dollars out of the country this year, seizing on the end of Covid precautions that had almost completely sealed China’s borders for nearly three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Role Does Humor Play in Your Life?
description: What makes you laugh these days?
content: It is often said that laughter is the best medicine. Do you agree? Why or why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: They Fled Climate Chaos. Asylum Law Made Decades Ago Might Not Help
description: “We need protection,” one migrant at the U.S. border said. But the legal system for refugees never envisioned the millions displaced by global warming.
content: First came the hurricanes — two storms, two weeks apart in 2020 — that devastated Honduras and left the country’s most vulnerable in dire need. In distant villages inhabited by Indigenous people known as the Miskito, homes were leveled and growing fields were ravaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: The 10 Best Books of 2023
description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s standout fiction and nonfiction.
content: Every year, starting in the spring, we spend months debating the most exceptional books that pass across our desks: the families we grow to love, the narrative nonfiction that carries us away, the fictional universes we can’t forget. It’s all toward one goal — deciding the best books of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Mellon Foundation Doubles Funding for U.S. Monuments, Pledging a Total $500 Million
description: The philanthropy will add to its ongoing initiative to tell diverse stories with new monuments in public spaces over the next five years.
content: Since 2020, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has spent nearly $173 million on 80 completed or ongoing monument projects across 37 states, supporting a broader and more diverse range of stories in the nation’s public spaces. On Tuesday, the arts and humanities philanthropy announced it would double its original commitment of $250 million over the next five years, pledging a total of $500 million for its Monuments Project.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dolly Parton (Really) Rocks
description: “Rockstar,” the country icon’s new double album of rock songs, is now the highest charting LP of her career. But her history with the genre runs deep.
content: At age 77, and with nearly 50 (!) solo studio releases to her name, Dolly Parton just scored the highest charting album of her career, the mammoth double LP “Rockstar,” which debuted on this week’s Billboard 200 at No. 3. (Darn those young whippersnappers Drake and Taylor Swift for standing in the way of Parton’s first No. 1!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Gavin Newsom Wants Fox News Viewers to Hear Him Out
description: After sparring twice with Sean Hannity, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California will jump into the ring this week with Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. The stakes are high for both men.
content: Gavin Newsom has a scant history of tough debates over his two decades as governor and lieutenant governor of California and mayor of San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Vorona Cote
title: Kids’ Books That Don’t Ignore the Dark Side of Life
description: It would be tempting to allow my son to believe in a world that will never betray him, but I want him to know better.
content: Last summer, I lost my heart to a peevish storybook turtle. This turtle — genderless, though for the sake of ease I’ll use “he” pronouns — might be forgiven for his mood. His days are riddled with mortal peril. In the watercolor milieu where he abides, boulders have a habit of plummeting from the sky, and a time-traveling Cyclopian monster roams the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong
title: What Makes a Vacuum Cleaner Sexy?
description: How Dyson’s cordless stick became a status symbol, a trophy of domesticity and a generational must-have.
content: When you imagine a life of luxury, what comes to mind? A mansion filled with walk-in closets the size of bedrooms? Garages housing sleek vehicles with German and Italian names?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Knowing When ‘They’ Means One
description: Saying “they wants” instead of “they want” could be easier to handle.
content: I have a proposal about our new usage of “they” to refer to individual people, as in, “Irene? Oh, they left an hour ago” or “Bernard cut themselves by accident.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Joseph Johnson
title: Sierra Leone Announces Arrest of 13 Military Officials in ‘Attempted Coup’
description: The West African nation has not identified the military officials and one civilian it arrested after attacks in the capital on Sunday that left 20 people dead and more than 2,000 prisoners on the loose.
content: The small West African nation of Sierra Leone announced on Tuesday that it had arrested 13 military officials and one civilian in connection with a thwarted coup attempt on Sunday, when 20 people were killed and more than 2,000 prisoners were let loose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France to Ban Smoking in Forests, on Beaches and Near Schools
description: A government anti-smoking plan also includes costlier cigarettes and a ban on disposable vapes. Smoking is the leading cause of avoidable deaths in France.
content: France will ban smoking on beaches, near public buildings like schools and in public parks and forests next year, the French government said on Tuesday, as it unveiled plans to curb the habit by making it slightly more expensive and far less attractive, especially to younger people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: At the Chicago Architecture Biennial, Artists Run Free
description: The directors, who are part of an art collective, wind up stretching architecture’s net in so many directions that it begins to fray.
content: Faheem Majeed, a member of the art collective the Floating Museum and one of the artistic directors of this year’s Chicago Architecture Biennial, was standing on a patch of soil on the South Side on a brisk, sunny afternoon last month. Next to him was the artist Erika Allen, a founder and the chief executive of Urban Growers Collective.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Helping Homeless People Who Are Mentally Ill
description: Responses to a Page 1 investigation. Also: An Oct. 7 observation; President Biden and the Israel-Gaza war; father, son and Jan. 6; planet Earth’s survival.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Strategic Dilemma
description: Israel’s leaders have big reasons to extend the temporary cease-fire — and big reasons to resume fighting.
content: Israel and Hamas have extended their truce for two days — through tomorrow — which will bring the pause in fighting to six days. The deal is a sign that both sides have benefited from it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Divya Victor
title: Poem: Settlement
description: The poem’s repetitions evoke the grim repetitions of history.
content: In Divya Victor’s “Settlement,” the poem’s repetitions evoke the grim repetitions of history. Even the poem’s prepositions are heavy and hard to bear. The string of “overs” that begin the poem are the “overs” of domination. The “we” of the poem are the “settled” who have become willfully insensate to history. They are left with the stark culmination of the Thanksgiving feast: a broken bone with no meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Cartier Ring Inspired by the Work of a 20th-Century Style Icon
description: The piece evokes a 1938 interlocking gold cuff designed by the house’s then creative director, Jeanne Toussaint.
content: In 1847, Louis-François Cartier opened a modest jewelry workshop in Paris where he sold crystal bracelets, strands of pearls and brooches with floral motifs. Over the decades, his three grandsons, particularly the eldest, Louis Cartier, became known for mixing Old World craftsmanship and new techniques, as in the 1904 Santos pilot’s watch, named for a pioneering Brazilian aviator and decorated with tiny screws resembling airplane rivets; or the so-called mystery clock, a timepiece popularized by the brand in 1912 with jeweled hands that appeared to float (its rack-and-pinion gear system was hidden in the base).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi Arabia to Host World Expo 2030, in Victory for Crown Prince
description: Winning the rights to host the major global event is a coup for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s efforts to remake the kingdom’s international image.
content: Saudi Arabia won the bid to host the World Expo 2030 in a landslide on Tuesday, delivering a triumph to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, as he seeks to reshape the authoritarian country’s international image — and his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: A Gaza Truce Aids Both Sides. Until the Calculus Changes.
description: Both Israel and Hamas are reaping benefits from the cease-fire, but as the hostage-for-prisoner exchanges continue, Israeli leaders may feel growing pressure to resume the war.
content: The decision by Israel and Hamas to extend their brief truce has created short-term benefits for both sides but amplified uncertainty about how, when and whether Israel will continue its invasion of the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francis Collins
title: We Are Squandering One of the Most Important Medical Advances of the 21st Century
description: Congress has a chance to eliminate hepatitis C in the United States.
content: A little over a decade ago, I watched my brother in-law Rick Boterf die of complications from infection with the hepatitis C virus that took his health, his vibrant energy and ultimately his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
title: C.I.A. Director Arrives in Qatar for Talks on Hostage Releases
description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. head, and David Barnea, who leads the Mossad, Israel’s spy service, are scheduled to meet with officials in Qatar, which has been mediating talks between Israel and Hamas.
content: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, arrived in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday for a new round of negotiations aimed at freeing more hostages held in Gaza, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden Navigates Divisions Over Gaza Inside the White House and Beyond
description: President Biden is facing deep anger over his solidarity with Israel among supporters and even from some staff members who have said they feel disenchanted with the president.
content: President Biden’s guests did not try to hide their anguish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Could a Drug Give Your Pet More Dog Years?
description: Longevity drugs for our canine companions are moving closer to reality. They also raise questions about what it might mean to succeed.
content: The life of a pet dog follows a predictable trajectory. Over time, the floppy-eared puppy that keeps falling asleep in his food bowl will become a lanky-legged adolescent with an insatiable interest in squirrels — before eventually settling into adulthood as a canine creature of habit, with a carefully chosen napping location and a well-rehearsed greeting ritual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: A Celebrated Street Food Market Will Return, in a Diminished State
description: After a city crackdown this summer, the vendors of Corona Plaza in Queens will return with far fewer stalls and hopes to expand.
content: Four months after New York City disbanded a celebrated but largely illegal street market in Queens that had exploded in popularity during the pandemic, the vendors are expected to return this week with far fewer stalls and, for now, none of the food that brought them acclaim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany to Override Debt Limit, Again, to Resolve Budget Crisis
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz pledged financial support for economic modernization and Ukraine, but will need backing for new borrowing to fill a spending gap.
content: Chancellor Olaf Scholz urged lawmakers on Tuesday to override Germany’s borrowing limits for a fourth consecutive year, allowing his government to take on billions of euros in fresh debt to modernize his country’s economy despite a budget crisis triggered by a constitutional court ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Israel and Hamas agreed to extend by two days a cease-fire that has brought a measure of calm to the Gaza Strip after seven weeks of intense warfare, the Qatari government said. The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and to allow more aid into the beleaguered area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Memorial Celebrates Rosalynn Carter’s Life, a ‘Public Love Story’
description: Former President Jimmy Carter emerged from hospice care to join a cast of political heavyweights paying tribute to Mrs. Carter, who died at 96 last week at her home in Plains, Ga.
content: Her journey took her from the smallest of small towns in rural Georgia to the majesty of the White House, from the campaign trails of Iowa and New Hampshire to refugee camps in Asia and impoverished villages in Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Shein’s Big I.P.O. Test
description: The fast-fashion giant is betting it can break the logjam of underperforming new listings, even as it continues to draw scrutiny from Washington.
content: In filing confidentially for an initial public offering, Shein, the ultrafast-fashion retailer, is showing ambition on two fronts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov, Roni Rabin and Talya Minsberg
title: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Tuesday
description: The group of 12 hostages, most of them Israelis, is the first to be released under the extended cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
content: Hamas released a group of 12 hostages on Tuesday, most of them Israelis or dual nationals but also including two Thai nationals, all of whom had been kidnapped during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 terrorist attacks in Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Wesley Parnell
title: After Students Target Pro-Israel Teacher, Officials Try to Quell Outrage
description: The New York schools chancellor promised disciplinary action but also called for understanding students’ viewpoint after hundreds at a Queens high school protested against a Jewish teacher.
content: New York City officials are investigating after hundreds of Queens high school students protested against a pro-Israel teacher, who was moved to another part of the building during the demonstration, the schools chancellor said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Bold Flavors in Fast Dishes
description: Soba noodles in ginger broth and jerk chicken meatballs are satisfying swerves from the creamy casseroles and slow bakes of Thanksgiving.
content: Hello, fellow home cooks. Genevieve here, filling in for Emily in the post-Thanksgiving, pre-holidays quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon Introduces Q, an A.I. Chatbot for Companies
description: Amazon has been racing to shake off the perception that it is lagging in the push to take advantage of artificial intelligence.
content: OpenAI has ChatGPT. Google has the Bard chatbot. Microsoft has its Copilots. On Tuesday, Amazon joined the chatbot race and announced an artificial intelligence assistant of its own: Amazon Q.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023.
content: A photo with an article on Monday about congressional retirements was published in error. The image of Carl Wilson, a former member of the Oregon House of Representatives, was included where an image of Representative Earl Blumenauer should have appeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Michael Rothfeld and William K. Rashbaum
title: Eric Adams’s Top Fund-Raiser Is Out Amid F.B.I. Scrutiny and Raid
description: The mayor had previously suggested that he had no intention of replacing the fund-raiser, Brianna Suggs.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York said on Tuesday that the 25-year-old woman he had chosen to manage his political fund-raising was no longer working in that role, weeks after a search of her home by the F.B.I. revealed a federal investigation into his campaign and plunged his administration into turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Not Quite on Time
description: You may detect shades of poetry in Gia Bosko’s puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking About the 10 Best Books of 2023
description: They’re here!
content: It’s that time of year: After months of reading, arguing and (sometimes) happily agreeing, the Book Review’s editors have come up with their picks for the 10 Best Books of 2023. On this week’s podcast, Gilbert Cruz reveals the chosen titles — five fiction, five nonfiction — and talks with some of the editors who participated in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Where the Flavors of the Amazon Rainforest Delight
description: In the food-obsessed port city of Belém, sweet, savory and sometimes addictive dishes are made with fresh ingredients that are tough to come by in Rio de Janeiro, let alone outside Brazil.
content: A foreign visitor walking through Praça Brasil, a leafy square in the Amazonian port city of Belém, might think that the whirring blenders at a dozen nearby food carts were creating the most authentic açaí bowls on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jean Knight, Who Struck Platinum With ‘Mr. Big Stuff,’ Dies at 80
description: Her anthem of female strength topped the Billboard R&B chart and reached No. 2 on the pop chart in 1971. Its appeal has endured.
content: Jean Knight, a soul singer whose memorable single “Mr. Big Stuff,” a brassy anthem of female strength, rose to No. 1 on Billboard’s rhythm and blues chart in 1971, died on Wednesday in Tampa, Fla. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Did That $4 Thrift Shop Painting Really Sell for $191,000? Nope.
description: A New Hampshire couple was quite happy when a rare N.C. Wyeth work they stumbled upon sold for so much at auction. But when the buyer reneged, the sale and their vacation dreams were undone.
content: To Tracy Donahue, the whole thing had felt like winning the lottery. And in a sense, she and her husband, Tom, had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith and Joe Rennison
title: Corporate America Has Dodged the Damage of High Rates. For Now.
description: Small businesses and risky borrowers face rising costs from the Federal Reserve’s moves, but the biggest companies have avoided taking a hit.
content: The prediction was straightforward: A rapid rise in interest rates orchestrated by the Federal Reserve would confine consumer spending and corporate profits, sharply reducing hiring and cooling a red-hot economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Mary Wilson, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rikki Novetsky, Lisa Chow, Lexie Diao, Diane Wong, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Will Reid and Alyssa Moxley
title: Israel and Hamas’s Fragile Cease-Fire
description: How a grass-roots campaign for the return of hostages managed to pause the war in Gaza.
content: Hostages are at the heart of the fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, now in its fifth day. As of Monday night, 50 Israeli hostages had been released, as had 150 Palestinian prisoners. More releases were expected on Tuesday, under what Qatari mediators said was a deal to extend the cease-fire by two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
title: Wife of Ukraine’s Spy Chief Was Poisoned, Officials Say
description: Marianna Budanova, whose husband is the director of military intelligence, is recovering in a hospital, the officials said. Her husband has long accused Russia of trying to kill him.
content: The wife of Ukraine’s military intelligence chief has been poisoned and is recovering in a hospital, Ukrainian intelligence officials said on Tuesday, an incident that has led to widespread speculation that Russia was stepping up efforts to target Ukraine’s senior leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Hostages freed by Hamas are experiencing cycles of euphoria followed by crashes, families say.
description: ‘Everything is just so fragile,’ said a cousin of the first two hostages freed last month.
content: Family members who were captured during the Hamas-led terrorist attacks on Oct. 7 who have now been freed are experiencing bursts of euphoria followed by emotional crashes as they emerge from weeks of paralyzing fear in captivity, according to Israelis who spoke to journalists at the Israeli Embassy in London on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Dreyer
title: A Giant Inland Sea Is Now a Desert, and a Warning for Humanity
description: The Aral Sea’s demise matters to us all.
content: Walking toward the shrinking remnants of what used to be the Aral Sea in Uzbekistan was like entering hell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Swiss Home So Well Designed It Needs Just One Door
description: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the Geneva apartment can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”
content: As their careers took them to various cities in Europe, the United States and Asia, Stef Claes and Michiel De Meulemeester, who are both Belgian, were used to leasing whatever lackluster apartments they could find. But when Mr. Claes, an architect, and Mr. De Meulemeester, a business executive who manages Mr. Claes’s firm, settled down in Geneva, they began thinking about creating a more appealing home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by The Learning Network
title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Cease Fire, Sam Altman, C.T.E.
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 11 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 11 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Convertible Apartment in Geneva
description: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the home can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”
content: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the home can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthias Joulaud and Lucien Roux
title: Ramboy
description: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.
content: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Rescuers Free 41 Workers Trapped in a Collapsed Indian Tunnel
description: The workers were trapped for more than two weeks after a landslide caused part of the tunnel they were building to collapse.
content: The workers were trapped for more than two weeks after a landslide caused part of the tunnel they were building to collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside Our List
description: Three New York Times Book Review editors share books from the “Best Books of 2023” list.
content: Three New York Times Book Review editors share books from the “Best Books of 2023” list.
source.name: The New York Times
